climbs.name: Back to Life
climbs.fa: Dean Mounsey, Adrian Nelhams & Peter Reid - Feb. 26th, 2020

content.description:
This is the line immediately to the left of Blue Monday, separated by a rock outcrop near the bottom. Pitch 1 - An initial short pitch, climbing the left edge of ‘Blue Monday’ and then traversing the narrow rock buttress via a wide ledge to the base of the ice. Pitch 2 - Great climbing up steepening, but stepped ice to an obvious ice belay at the base of the steep curtain of ice on ‘Blue Monday’ Pitch 3 - Undulating ice leads on to the top of the route 2 rappels on v threads gets you down. Follow approach directions for Corona Creek.

The top of this climb is visible from Hwy 11 and also about three quarters of the way into the approach it will become obvious on your left hand side. Standard ice rack.

Pitch 1 (WI4, 50m) - Climb 50 meters of good steep ice broken up every so often with a rest spot to an ice belay in a cave on the right. Pitch 2 (WI4, 40m) - Fire up a steep section out of the cave and choose your line after, belay on the right either on trees or ice. Pitch 3 (WI2-3, 30m) Continue up and left around a rock band to a tree belay on top of the rock. Two 60 meter rappels will get you down just barely. Follow approach directions for Corona Creek.

The top of this climb is visible from Hwy 11 and also about three quarters of the way into the approach it will become obvious on your left hand side. Standard ice rack.

climbs.name: Swipe Right
climbs.fa: Dean Mounsey, Adrian Nelhams, & Peter Reid - Feb. 26th, 2020

content.description:
Swipe Right is 120m of beautiful blue ice rolling down inside a small canyon that opens up at the top of the route. Climb in 2 or 3 pitches with ice belays where it makes sense. Descent via v threads. Follow approach directions for Corona Creek.

Swipe Right will only come into view once you are almost below it. It is the first flow of ice you will see on the right, immediately opposite of Blue Monday. Standard ice rack.

Corona Creek is the creek coming out of an obscure and quiet valley found between Triangle Peak and Corona Ridge. The valley contains a few recently discovered ice routes near its beginning, and a few unclaimed lines deeper still.  
  
 Access is arduous as it involves first crossing the North Saskatchewan River either with care by foot if it is frozen over, or by a boat if not. That being said, if you are up for the adventure and want to spend the entire day not seeing a soul and climbing some ice very few people will ever see, this is the place.
